subject: Re: [junit] Planning Unit Tests
msgSnippet: In the beginning, people will be learning to write tests, so there will be a lot of overhead. After a while, people will be learning to write good tests and
messageBody:
In the beginning, people will be learning to write tests, so there will be a lot of overhead.

After a while, people will be learning to write good tests and will begin refactoring, so there will be a bit of overhead.

After a while, people will already be writing good tests and won't need to refactor as much, so there will be zero overhead.

After that -- FOREVER -- people will go faster because features will be easier to add and the old code will be much better.

How long and how much overhead is tougher to indicate.

Mr. Project Manager: are you willing to invest time and money into learning so that every other project in the lifetime of the company can go faster?


So said artisanzero on 4/3/2003 --------------------
A group of developers were recently asked whether an additional 10%
of design/code time was adequate to write unit tests. I'm interested
in feedback regarding what others think is adequate. I am not
interested in why the question itself is incorrect, I know that. If
you were shown a project plan, told that unit tests weren't worked
into the schedule, but that they should be, and asked what percentage
of time should be added - what would you say. Keep in mind the
positive - management wants unit tests included and is willing to
consider allotting time.

Some background:
Initial requirements are complete. This is a major new version of an
existing product - new requirements, but not entirely new domain. The
planning is iterative, with medium-length development cycles that
look like small waterfalls.

Any thoughts?
